title: Hi, I'm WeirdyBeardy, Creative & Esports Publishing Lead at Riot OCE - Ask Me Anything!
body:
_**EDIT - Thanks for your questions everyone, great getting to know you. I'm heading offline now, but expect to see more of me around here :) **_

Hey everyone!

I'm Kieran 'WeirdyBeardy' Weir - half man, half beard, half adc (maths was never my strong point). I've just relocated to Riot OCE from Riot EU, working in our creative and esports teams to deliver local content and experiences that (hopefully!) you guys will enjoy, such as [League of Origin](http://oce.lolesports.com/articles/introducing-league-legends-league-origin-76914)!

Shameless plugs aside - before Riot I worked at Xbox, NCsoft and Eurogamer, working across writing, design, tech and video. I've been playing games for over 30 years, so I find it _very_ hard to shortlist my favourites, but here's a try... Halo (all), (any) Mario, The Last of Us, Portal, Half-Life, Doom and Shadow of the Colossus. And ICO. And FIFA. And Rocket League. And League. See?

I have a pretty extensive collection of retro games and machines spanning the 80s and 00s (left back in the UK, *sob*). Outside of games, I am a trained coffee barista, love (but suck at) photography, my favourite film is Jim Henson's Labyrinth (don't judge me) and band is Queen's of the Stone Age.

Something that no-one here knows is that I was once on a UK videogames TV show where I bailed out in the Grand Finals by getting a question about Tekken's Paul Phoenix wrong. Live on TV. The shame of it. Still haunts me.

OK, enough about me... go ahead, ask me anything!

Heya Weirdy

I'm curious, because I'm unsure if I've seen you in the local scene, what experience and past roles bought you to Riot OCE?

also, on a scale of 1-10, how weird is your beard?

Hey Jason!

I arrived in Australia from the UK in January - I've been in Riot for almost four years now, the majority of that spent working in Europe where I ran our local creative team. A lot of the products we created there were with the EU LCS team in Berlin, anything from branding to stage design to building the Lolesports.com platform so we could publish localised esports content.

Before Riot I've had a variety of roles mainly on the publishing side of games, or the creative side in agencies - but even in the latter, I was always keen to keep a hand in games, either working with gaming clients or developing mini-games for other clients.

I'm 18 years into my career, and have worked in a real variety of roles, I could feel the pull of something combining esports and creative as my next move and that's what brought me to OCE - looking forward to really getting stuck into things here!

No doubt OCE has its challenges in being an "up-and-coming region", but where do you think the region has an edge over competing regions (if anywhere)?

Hey Eshanes :)

You're totally right, many challenges. If I think about the OPL in the same way I think about a startup (it is still relatively new by comparison), I'm excited about what's ahead of us - successful startups are defined by their strength of vision, the velocity of getting things done and the will of those involved to win. I've only been in Riot OCE a short time, but I know already that I'm surrounded by likeminded people who share those traits and ambitions.

Looking at the OPL, I believe the way we create that edge is by dialling up our support and promotion of the players and teams in the league - that's our point of differentiation, that's what is truly unique to OPL. I'm keen to start working with players to start telling those stories, and building those profiles, in the hope that the fans and support will rally behind them even more. More support = More wins (scientifically proven).

On top of that, and from what I've seen so far, OCE fans are super passionate (I think sport is a bit of a thing here?), so combined with the above, I think we have an incredible future in front of us.

Btw, Sin vs Avant Garde on [right now](http://watch.oce.lolesports.com)... who's your money on? :)
I thought to myself last week; whoever loses the Week 10 match will win the first gauntlet game so I'll stick with Sin. Looking good after the first game! The masters of the quick win.

Hey FiveToEight!

Dude, your videos are anything but shitty - big fan! In terms of turning your hobby into a career, my recommendation would be to build up your portfolio as much as you can and send it out to any companies or people that you want to work with, if you can tailor either what you're doing to be relevant/resonant with that company or person, all the better, or try to target those who would be receptive to what you want to produce.

I'm knew to the region, but try posting things up to video sites for professionals (e.g. portfolio sites or work for hire sites) that invite peers to comment and feedback on your work. Being an active voice in the community is a great way to get visibility.

On a side note, we should meet up, maybe there's something we could work on together in the future :)

Greetings WeirdyBeardy,

Firstly, love the name, as a person who has a beard myself I highly approve. As for my questions though, got two serious ones and two fun ones for you:

* Being the creative/eSports Publishing lead at Riot OCE, I am curious what exactly does the role "lead" entail? Is it the fact that you get to choose the direction projects go in within the teams you work with? Or is it more a supervision/passing out of work while handling projects yourself as well?


* In the creative side of things, for people who you work with at Riot OCE, do you value having people with a wide spread out skill set? Or do you prefer those who have their one area really mastered?


* What was your first video game as a kid?


* Assuming you came up with your name because of a weird beard, how weird was said beard?

Thank you, and nice to meet you!

~Elam

Hey Elam, my fellow bearded brother!

Nice to meet you too, thanks for the questions...

Being a lead at Riot means that you are accountable for the success or failure of whatever team it is you're leading - it's on leads to articulate a problem or opportunity space, set the mission, goals etc and then collaborate with other Rioters to find ways to tackle it. We support the effort and ensure the team has what it needs to deliver on it, and then take all the credit for the win (jk).

Honestly, we value both. We look for 'T' shaped Rioters, those who a breadth of skills/abilities and depth in their craft expertise - the OCE team is relatively small, so having people here that can tackle a wide variety of tasks is really important, but at the same time, you know that those same people can deliver the very best in their craft.

My first computer was a ZX Spectrum (128K!), and the very first cassette I loaded in was a text adventure for The Never Ending Story. It took an hour to load, but I can still remember it so clearly, I mapped the whole thing out on paper and died in the Swamp of Sadness so many times - it took me months and months to crack it.

Haha, my beard is probably the least weird thing about me (my so-called friends tell me) - it was inspired by my surname and the fact I have a pretty big beard - [this guy](http://www.huffingtonpost.com.au/entry/ramen-beard_n_3982332) wins the weird beard thing, hands down :)

Thanks for the response mate!

Always cool to learn more about the inner workings of how the roles in Riot are set up and thank you going for the detail on what sort of Rioters are looked for in creative fields. Its a very interesting analogy using a 'T' and it works quite well, I will have to keep this in mind when developing my own craft as Its my dream to become a Rioter one day.

Thank you as well for the answers to the fun questions, my first game was smash brothers for the N64 and yeap, that guy 100% wins the beard thing.

~Elam

No problem man - love smash bros!

What kind of area are you looking to get into? Def worth checking out the [Riot Careers group](https://www.linkedin.com/groups/3544410) on LinkedIn - tons of discussion, ideas, news, advice etc.

Thanks for the link, I hadn't heard in the past there was a group on LinkedIn so I will for sure check this out.

As for area I am looking to get into, really I like creative areas myself. Currently doing a diploma of Graphic Design and that's the main area I work in at the moment doing it as a freelancer working for Legacy eSports as their designer. (Have been for 2 years, designing for over 5 years) 

Apart from that I gotta admit I am really loving doing all this stuff for the community as a volunteer, running events and discussions and interacting with them. So as crazy as it sounds, if there would be some sort of middle ground where I could do both it would be amazing, but I would mainly lean towards design if I had to pick. Also a big fan of eSports as well, I like a lot of areas of work, also having worked in IT in the past xD

If you have any advice it would highly appreciated, but I know the main thing to do is to focus on mastering on my craft and always looking for ways to improve, which is what I am doing at the moment while doing stuff for the community as a volunteer.

Thank you again mate! 

~Elam

Sounds like you're doing great! You're focusing on your craft *and* getting some solid, relevant xp under your belt - honestly, keep doing what you're doing - build your portfolio and interact and be a part of the design community, and you'll be surprised where it takes you.

Hey Vendra,

We've tried a few different approaches on the recap articles, we know that people don't want to read a wall of text that goes blow-by-blow into every event in the game, although it's easy to fall into that trap. The casters are a great gauge of which beats in the game are pivotal to the end result, a teamfight, Baron steal or just straight up 1v1 that ends badly - these are the areas to go deeper on in the wider context of the match. If you can add flavour by including a deep-link into a VOD, even better, say it then show it. We're producing video weekly OPL recaps now, wondering if you'd seen any of those?
